availability.p: All research and writing of Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition annotations was undertaken by project staff, volunteers, and interns. Each record contains citations to relevant primary and secondary source material. All annotations are copyright Kentucky Historical Society, and should be referenced as such in any published work.

seriesStmt.title: Civil War Governors of Kentucky Digital Documentary Edition

person.persName: George Washington Dupee (Lexington, Kentucky, free black Baptist pastor)

body.p: Lexington, Kentucky, pastor. Kentucky native. Son of Cuthbert Dupee and Rachael Dupee. Enslaved from 1827 to 1856. Freed by purchase by Pleasant Green Baptist Church in Lexington, Kentucky, in 1856. Pastor of Pleasant Green Baptist Church in Lexington to 1864. Organized first Association of African American churches in 1864. Pastor of Washington Street Colored Baptist Church in Paducah, Kentucky, in 1864.

ab.bibl:
Eighth Manuscript Census of the United States (1860), Population Schedules, Kentucky, Fayette County, Lexington, Ward 2, p. 412.
Find A Grave, "Rev. G. W. Dupee (July 7, 1827-September 5, 1897), Memorial #83942189, https://www.findagrave.com/memorial/83942189 (accessed May 27, 2017).
"George W Dupee," Notable Kentucky African Americans Databas, University of Kentucky Libraries, http://nkaa.uky.edu/record.php?note_id=1195 (accessed May 27, 2017).
